sub_topic: Calculation of the electrical conductivity of a metal
message_1: Determine the electrical conductivity of pure copper at a temperature of 300 K, given that its resistivity is 1.68 x 10^-8 Ωm.
message_2:
Electrical conductivity (σ) is the reciprocal of resistivity (ρ). The formula to find the electrical conductivity is:

σ = 1 / ρ

Given the resistivity of pure copper (ρ) is 1.68 x 10^-8 Ωm at 300 K, we can find the electrical conductivity using the formula:

σ = 1 / (1.68 x 10^-8 Ωm)

σ ≈ 5.95 x 10^7 S/m

The electrical conductivity of pure copper at a temperature of 300 K is approximately 5.95 x 10^7 S/m (Siemens per meter).
